opened_prs.title: contract/deploy: avoid bash error exit
opened_prs.body:
<!--
Contributions welcome! See https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/.github/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

**Description**

<!--
A clear and concise description of the features you're adding in this pull request.
-->
This is a follow up PR of https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/pull/14594. 

When I'm running the deploy on Linux, met the below error: 

```
  FaultDisputeGame_255 deployed at 0x80c36401333dE87E48b5e8C6D387444Bf127D9E2
  DisputeGameFactoryProxy: set `FaultDisputeGame` implementation (Backend: Alphabet | GameType: 255)
  Setting SuperFaultDisputeGame implementation
Error: script failed: FfiFailed("Command: bash -c [[ -f /code/op-stack/optimism/packages/contracts-bedrock/../../op-program/bin/prestate-proof-interop.json ]] && echo \"present\" \nError: ")
```

I'm not sure this is Linux's default behavior or just my case, if the file not exists, then the command's exit code is not zero:

```bash
[[ -f xxx ]] && echo present
echo $? # return 1

[[ -f xxx ]] && echo present || echo 
echo $? # return 0
```

So I think we can append a `||` to catch the notmatched case, in a more robust way. 

Or another fix is use `vm.exists` instead, but it need to add the json files into foundry's `fs_permissions`


**Tests**

Please describe any tests you've added. If you've added no tests, or left important behavior untested, please explain why not.
-->

The local-safe value in the status appears to be zeroed sometimes, when it shouldn't be.

opened_prs.title: op-service: tx plans
opened_prs.body:
**Description**

This PR introduces the idea of a "tx plan".
Plans are build on `PlannedTx` instances.

Each such instance has tx-attributes you can depend on, and whose changes invalidate the downstream dependencies.

Each of the tx-attributes can also be programmed to automatically update based on environmental changes. These updates can also be built as `Option` pattern, for reusability. E.g. a gas-estimator which simulates the tx, every time the tx message changes, and optionally dependent on an outside block, to automatically invalidate the estimate when it's stale.

This enables you to e.g. define Tx B, with a tx-input that depends on the receipt of tx A, declaratively.

Another example is to chain the nonces of txs, by making txB depend on the nonce of txA: whenever the nonce of A changes, the nonce of B is invalidated and re-evaluated with it.

Different graphs of planned txs can be formed, and then applied all at once.

Planned txs can also be wrapped, to add application-meaning to them. E.g. an attribute that depends on the receipt of another tx.

**Tests**

- unit-tests with full coverage for the new `plan.Lazy[V]` type
- some unit tests for the `PlannedTx`
- work in progress interop test example

**Additional context**

The utils are a bit involved, but the aim is to make the future of tx-planning fully declarative and make all features of a tx reusable, as well as easy to relate between different txs.

**Metadata**

Fix #14529

opened_prs.title: feat(op-wheel): add update-finality flag to control safe and finalized blocks updates
opened_prs.body:
### Description
This PR adds a new flag --update-finality to the op-wheel engine commands that controls whether safe and finalized blocks should be updated during auto mode. The flag is added to both engine block and engine auto commands, allowing users to control the finality behavior of the chain. When enabled, the flag causes the engine to update safe and finalized blocks during "beacon epoch transitions" (every 32 blocks).
This implementation resolves the TODO comments about adding a finalize/safe flag in the codebase.
### Tests
The changes are primarily focused on adding a new configuration option to existing functionality. The existing functionality is already well-tested, and this change simply makes the finality update behavior configurable rather than always enabled.
The implementation follows the same pattern as other flags in the codebase, such as --allow-gaps.
### Additional context
This change improves the flexibility of the op-wheel tool by allowing users to control whether finality updates should occur during auto mode. This can be useful in testing scenarios where users want to simulate different finality behaviors.
### Metadata
Fixes the TODO comments in op-wheel/commands.go related to adding a finalize/safe flag.

opened_prs.title: Fix: Prevent negative values in pendingDABytes metric
opened_prs.body:
### Description
This PR fixes issue #14518 where the batcher's pendingDABytes metric could become negative, causing it to get stuck at 6MB and unnecessarily throttle the sequencer.

The fix ensures pendingDABytes never goes below zero by implementing atomic compare-and-swap logic in RecordL2BlockInChannel.

Added a test to verify the fix prevents negative values.

closed_prs.body:
<!--
Contributions welcome! See https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/.github/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

**Description**

We're tagging dev releases of monorepo components with `latest` because our script excludes by pattern-matching `rc` instead of negatively matching finalized releases. This fixes it.

Note that this is similar to https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/op-geth/pull/515 but doesn't require the tag to start with `v` so the `^` in the regexp is missing because the monorepo has component-prefixed tags.

opened_issues.title: OP-Conductor health check ignores the `OP_CONDUCTOR_HEALTHCHECK_UNSAFE_INTERVAL` configuration option
opened_issues.body:
**Bug Description**

The op-conductor health check ignores the `OP_CONDUCTOR_HEALTHCHECK_UNSAFE_INTERVAL` configuration option.

**Steps to Reproduce**

To exacerbate the problem for reproducibility's sake start a local devnet with a 1 second block time and `OP_CONDUCTOR_HEALTHCHECK_UNSAFE_INTERVAL` set to 60 seconds. Give the batcher a max time of 1.5 hours.

In the conductor logs you will find:

```
t=2025-02-27T22:12:39+0000 lvl=error msg="unsafe head is not progressing as expected" now=1740694359 unsafe_head_num=522782 last_seen_unsafe_num=522782 last_seen_unsafe_time=1740694357 unsafe_interval=60 time_diff=2 block_diff=0 expected_blocks=1
```

And then the conductor will select a new leader. You will notice that op-conductor fails over to new sequencers alarmingly often.

**Expected behavior**

There should be no sequencer failover.

In the example above op-conductor evaluates that it expected 1 block and got 0 so it should pick a new leader. This ignores the `OP_CONDUCTOR_HEALTHCHECK_UNSAFE_INTERVAL` option which should allow the sequencer to be up to 60 seconds behind.


**Environment Information:**

- Operating System: Ubuntu 20.04.6 LTS (Focal Fossa)
- Package Version (or commit hash): op-node v1.10.2, op-conductor v0.2.0

**Configurations:**

OP_CONDUCTOR_HEALTHCHECK_INTERVAL: "1"
OP_CONDUCTOR_HEALTHCHECK_MIN_PEER_COUNT: "1"
OP_CONDUCTOR_HEALTHCHECK_UNSAFE_INTERVAL: "60"

**Logs:**

```
t=2025-02-27T22:12:39+0000 lvl=error msg="unsafe head is not progressing as expected" now=1740694359 unsafe_head_num=522782 last_seen_unsafe_num=522782 last_seen_unsafe_time=1740694357 unsafe_interval=60 time_diff=2 block_diff=0 expected_blocks=1
```

**Additional context**

This [PR](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/pull/9248) introduced the bug in the health check.

opened_issues.title: op-batcher: testing API
opened_issues.body:
A gap between action-tests and full system tests is the op-batcher:
for some tests, we need control when the batch is wrapped-up and submitted.

After the op-test-sequencer work is done, a simple op-batcher API to influence the batch scheduler may be enough.

Currently the batcher determines when to submit batches based on the buffered data,
the time, and the sync state of the attached node.

With an RPC, we can ideally change what L2 blocks are in scope,
and override when the buffer is considered full enough to submit to L1.

E.g.:
- `batcher_setL2Scope`: limit the view over the L2 chain
- `batcher_submitNow`: force-submit the current data, even if the buffer is not full yet
- `batcher_cursors`: check where the cursor (submitted L2 block, different stages maybe) is at.

Tests can then use these to make the batcher submit txs when we want that.
The test-sequencer can then receive the tx from a regular `eth_sendRawTransaction` RPC, and confirm it in the right L1 block.

opened_issues.title: op-node: post-interop cleanup

labels.name: H-interop
labels.description: Hardfork: change planned for interop upgrade

opened_issues.body:
With the Interop features, and the op-supervisor DB tracking data, we have an opportunity to remove parts of the op-node.

There may be a way to accelerate this ahead of the interop upgrade, if we embed the op-supervisor functionality inside of op-node, or start using op-supervisor ahead of the interop fork (the chains config can prevent interop messages by timestamp).

## Find-sync-start

The algorithm we rely on to determine the sync-starting-point is something we want to deprecate.
It's complicated, fragile to RPC errors, and slows down the node startup and resets.
But we can soon remove it!

With interop, the op-supervisor maintains a safety-index,
to determine which L2 blocks were submitted when, and when the blocks become cross-safe.
As soon as interop becomes the default, nodes can rely on this safety-index
for a single almost-instantaneous API query to determine where to start syncing from.

To handle historical pre-interop sync, we will need to have a retroactive safety-index,
or remove syncing from historical L1 data, to not need this functionality more.

This cuts the `/op-node/rollup/sync` package.

## Finality

Like find-sync-start, finality is maintained differently pre-interop than post-interop.
Pre-interop we needed to maintain an in-memory buffer of past seen derivation updates,
and match that against incoming L1 finality signals, to determine what is safe to finalize.

With a persistent database of past derivation updates, the in-memory buffer is no longer necessary.
The op-supervisor can instantly report what L2 block is finalized, given any L1 finality scope.

This cuts the `/op-node/rollup/finality` package.

## Safedb

Op-node currently maintains a database with a mapping of when a L2 block has been derived from a L1 block.
This serves the fault-proofs API to query what L2 block can be contested for what game
(a specific L1 chain scope the L2 block needs to be reproducible from).

With interop, since we are tracking cross-safety, we already maintain this data,
in a more detailed, more safe and more systematic way.
So, once the op-supervisor becomes the default, we can remove the SafeDB tracking.

This cuts the `/op-node/node/safedb` package, and simplifies the `/op-node/node/node` package.

opened_issues.title: op-node: block signing and publishing improvements
opened_issues.body:
In summary:

- Signing block happens inefficiently, at the less-than-ideal time, and can use documentation.
- Publishing blocks happens with bottleneck and at the less-than-ideal time.
- Committing blocks and sequencer rotation is prone to async-gossip race conditions.

Signing efficiency is fixed with https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/pull/14478
combined with https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/infra/pull/203

And the V2 API fixes the typing, so alternative remote-signer services can be implemented, on top of a sane API format.

Blocks are currently "async-gossiped". This becomes obsolete with flash-blocks, and never won us that much time.
It did however add fragility: when a block is committed to conductor before it is published,
then there is a continuation issue, where other nodes cannot continue without receiving the missing block.

The conductor does post the missing block with `admin_postUnsafePayload`,
but that doesn't retry or lock, which means the conductor can still fail to handover sequencer control
when the block has not been processed yet, even after success-response.

On top of that, the conductor does not get the block-signature, nor posts the signature back to the node.
This makes sequencer-rotation extra difficult, since a block from the conductor cannot be published to verifiers.
So when the sequencer rotation fails, there can be a verifier hiccup where the block is temporarily missing, since the conductor does not post it everywhere, and block cannot be gossiped out without signature.

We should make the sequencer:

- Handle block signing/committing/posting as following:
    - Sign the block before committing to it.
    - Post the signature to the conductor, and include the signature.
    - Receive the block from the conductor with a commit-API, with signature, *synchronously*,
    to ensure the block is there before rotating sequencer responsibility to the node.
    - Receive the block from the conductor with a publish-API, with signature, to republish.
- Start using the V2 API:
    - Roll out the op-signer change with the V2 block-signing method
    - Add v2-block-signing flag to op-node, see [[issue 14499](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/issues/14499)](https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/issues/14499)
    - Document the V2 API format

V2 API usage is low-lift and can happen today.
The signing/committing/posting improvement may not be worth it,
and instead lean on the sequencing work to get completed.

opened_issues.title: op-node: cleanup signal / schedule internals
opened_issues.body:
RPC APIs of the op-node are clobbered in the main package.

Signals (incoming blocks, new safety updates) are routed through the node,
to the driver, to the driver-state, to the state-loop, sync-deriver, to the event system.
Too many steps, we can cut and simplify a lot of the code there.

API backends should be encapsulated objects, attached to the event-system.
Then the right events can just be fired when they come in, without extra steps.

This largely cuts the scheduling situation in the `/op-node/rollup/driver` package:

- All the sub-systems we register in the monolith, we only register because of the above round-about way of updating it.
- We shouldn't have to "poll" for events in the driver state-loop. All follow-up work is already scheduled as events.
Draining the event-executor is all that's necessary. This is a stupid-simple call, and can happen outside of the driver.

opened_issues.title: op-node: cleanup engine package
opened_issues.body:
The `op-node/rollup/engine` package wraps the engine event-refactor around a legacy `EngineController`.
To this engine controller there are synchronous methods attached, implementing CL-Sync and pre-Holocene functionality.
The engine-controller should be simplified.

We are also currently instrumenting the engine for better test access:
we attach a minimal API (`Open, Cancel, Seal, Commit`) to the engine, such that we can control
block building / processing in tests, without duplicating the engine-API code or creating conflicting forkchoice updates.
This API is important for testing (action-test abilities become widely available) and
the test-sequencer code (crafted block templates need to be processed and persisted).

Also see https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/issues/14260

opened_issues.title: op-service: Go service templating
opened_issues.body:
The current services in the monorepo are not templated, but do follow similar patterns. Refactoring existing ones will be a big effort, but services should not be difficult to set up.

We have two options:
1. introduce service templating in Go, refactor to use the template as much as we can over time, to not de-dup code.
2. keep the service patterns similar.

Option 2 is the more viable solution for now. A good example of a service scaffolding can be found here: https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/pull/14270 

Long-term we do want to adopt option (1) for more dry code.

opened_issues.title: op-program: Add subcommand to list all supported chains
opened_issues.body:
Add a sub command to op-program host to list all known chains and their hard fork configuration.

As part of the release build, run the subcommand and publish the result somewhere.

This would make it easy to determine which chains are supported by a release and whether the latest hard fork configuration is included for them.

opened_issues.title: OPCM: ensure contract `upgrade` methods are called in `opcm.upgrade`

labels.name: go
labels.description: Pull requests that update Go code

opened_issues.body:
We need to ensure that, if any L1 source contracts that have an `upgrade` method, that upgrade method is called in the `OPContractsManager.upgrade` method. Ideally, if OPCM was missing this, tests would fail. But that will not always be the case, so we should have a go script to traverse the AST to verify this. The spec is roughly:

- Collect all `upgrade` functions from the L1 artifacts
- Look at the AST for `OPCM.upgrade(..)`
- Make sure that the AST contains a function call to `X.upgrade` for each X in step 1

cc @maurelian @smartcontracts

opened_issues.title: op-batcher: Improve pending data tracking

labels.name: T-protocol
labels.description: Team: changes to node components (op-node, op-reth, etc.) implemented by go/rust/etc. devs

opened_issues.body: Sequencer throttling is currently entirely based on the amount of pending-da-bytes of data before getting into any channel, and this data is estimated using FastLZ compression per block, and adding a fixed 70 bytes overhead. We completely ignore the amount of data currently queued in channels (of which there are another two kinds, those already in submission, and those in the channel queue not in submission yet). So if the batcher has a low number of pending transactions configured, throttling is getting activated faster. And also just after loading a heap of blocks, it would immediately throttle, because those blocks didn't find its way into channels yet, but then in the next tick of the data submission loop would add all of those pending blocks into channels and the throttling would be lifted again. Not ideal behavior.

wartime_milady_ceo_summary: - **Summary of the Week's PRs and Issues**: This week's activity in the repository was predominantly focused on maintenance and hardening efforts, with a few feature enhancements and bug fixes. The tone of the pull requests and issues suggests a meticulous approach to refining existing functionalities and ensuring robustness, particularly in the context of Ethereum Optimism's complex system architecture.

- **PR #14589 - Bytecode Verification Script**: This pull request introduced a script designed to verify that the bytecode in local artifacts matches the bytecode of a deployed contract on a live network. This enhancement is crucial for developers to ensure consistency and correctness in contract deployments, thereby reducing potential discrepancies and errors in smart contract execution.
